Diagnosis: Cirrhosis (due to chronic liver disease) Justification: Symptoms such as fatigue, abdominal distension, early satiety, and weight loss are typical of decompensated cirrhosis, which is common in advanced liver disease.  3. Diagnosis: Gastrointestinal peptic ulcer disease Justification: Can cause hematemesis, though less likely given the context of portal hypertension and cirrhosis.  10. Diagnosis: Liver failure (hepatic encephalopathy or hepatic decompensation) Justification: Advanced liver deterioration causes systemic effects, including hepatic encephalopathy, contributing to overall clinical decline.
